Simulation for digital holograms on tilted planeshttps://opg.optica.org/oe/fulltext.cfm?uri=oe-13-24-9935&id=86288 $$\hat{O}(d;u,v) = O(u,v)exp[i2\pi d (\lambda ^{-2}-u^2-v^2)]$$ $$u=\xi/\lambda d, v=\eta/\lambda d$$ $O(u,v) = F{o(x,y)}$ is the spectrum of the object at $z=0$. We then rotate the wave vector coordinates $k=2\pi[u,v,w],w=(\lambda ^{-2}-u^2-v^2)^{1/2}$. Consider 3D rotation matrix (clockwise rotation): we can get rotated wave vector components $k=2\pi[\hat{u},\hat{v},\hat{w}],\hat{u}=u\cos\theta -w\sin \theta, \hat{v} =v,\hat{w}=u\sin\theta+w\cos\theta$. $$u = \hat{u}\cos\theta + \hat{w}\sin\theta$$ Therefore, $\hat{O}(d;\hat{u},\hat{v})=\hat{O}(d;\hat{u}\cos\theta+\hat w\sin\theta,\hat{v})$ Before application of the inverse Fourier transform, the grids have to be mapped into a uniformly spaced frequency grid using interpolation methods. Finally, $o(\hat{x},\hat{y}) = F^{-1}\hat{O}(d;\hat{u}\cos\theta+\hat w\sin\theta,\hat{v})$

pages.title: Yuhang Li
pages.text: Hi! My name is Yuhang Li (李煜航). I am currently a Ph.D. student at UCLA’s Bio- and Nano-photonics Lab, working under the supervision of Professor Aydogan Ozcan. I earned my Bachelor of Engineering (BEng) degree in June 2021 from Zhejiang University, China. My current research focuses on computational imaging and optical neural networks. News Sept, 2024 - Emil Wolf Outstanding Student Paper Competition at FiO+LS 2024 Mar, 2024 - Advanced to candidacy for the doctoral degree Feb, 2024 - Three oral presentations at SPIE PW 2024 Aug, 2023 - Best early career researcher presentation, Silver at SPIE Optics + Photonics 2023 Sept, 2021 - Joined UCLA Bio- and Nano-photonics Lab Jul, 2021 - Graduated from Zhejiang University with the bachelor of engineering Selected PublicationsFull publications list here
